persona_description: Samantha is a 24-year-old retail manager living in suburban Atlanta with a high school diploma and a lower-middle income. She is engaged and has limited access to healthcare, relying on occasional visits to a free clinic. Samantha is overweight, sedentary, and smokes occasionally, but has no chronic conditions. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not currently taking prenatal vitamins.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Medical Research Interview - Session Begin

Thank you so much for taking the time to meet with me today, Samantha. I really appreciate your willingness to participate in this research. 

Before we dive in, I want you to know that this is a safe, confidential space. There are no wrong answers here—I'm just trying to understand your experiences and what you're going through. If any question feels too personal or you'd rather not answer, just let me know and we can skip it. Does that sound okay?

---

Let me start with some foundational questions to help me understand your situation better.

**First, I'd like to confirm: You're currently pregnant, correct? And this is your first pregnancy?** How far along are you, if you don't mind me asking?

And then I'm curious—**how are you feeling about the pregnancy overall?** I know from your background information that you mentioned being uncertain about your pregnancy plans. I'd like to hear more about that in your own words, if you're comfortable sharing.

Take your time with your responses. There's no rush.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Samantha's Response

*shifts in seat, tucking hair behind ear*

Yeah, um... okay. Well, like I said, I'm 24, and I work as a manager at a retail store here in the suburbs—it's not glamorous or anything, but it pays the bills, mostly. I'm engaged to my fiancé; we've been together for about four years now, so that's... that's good, I guess.

*fidgets with hands*

As for the pregnancy—yes, I'm pregnant. This is my first one. I'm about 16 weeks along now, so I'm in my second trimester. And honestly? *pauses, looking down* I'm... I'm still processing it all. We weren't exactly planning this right now. Don't get me wrong, my fiancé is supportive, but we haven't set a wedding date yet, and I'm still figuring out if I'm ready to be a mom, you know? There's a lot going on.

*looks up*

As for my life situation—I mean, we're doing okay financially, but it's tight. I don't have health insurance through work, so I've been going to the free clinic when I really need to. My fiancé has some coverage, but it's not great. We live in a decent apartment, nothing fancy. I smoke sometimes when I'm stressed—I know that's probably not great, especially now—and I'm not super active. I know I should be, but between work and everything else...

*trails off*

Is there anything specific you want to know?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and nods*

Yeah, so... I found out about three weeks ago, actually. It was kind of a shock, to be honest. I missed my period, and at first I just thought, you know, maybe it was late or stress or whatever. But then I started feeling really tired—like, exhausted all the time—and my boobs were tender. So I picked up a pregnancy test at the drugstore, did it at home, and... there it was. Two lines.

*laughs nervously*

I remember just staring at it for like five minutes, not really believing it. I called my fiancé right away, and he came home from work early. We just kind of sat there in shock for a while, honestly.

*shifts in seat*

I didn't go to the clinic right away because, I don't know, I was still trying to process it myself. But then I went in about a week later because I wanted to confirm it was real and get some information. That's when they did the blood test and everything, and yeah, it's definitely real. I'm about 16 weeks now based on what they calculated from my last period.

*looks down at hands*

The thing is, I haven't really told many people yet. Just my fiancé and my mom. And I haven't... I haven't started taking prenatal vitamins or anything like that. I know I probably should, but I'm still kind of in denial, I think. Like, if I don't do all the "pregnancy stuff," maybe it feels less real?

*pauses*

Does that make sense?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods thoughtfully*

Yeah, so like I mentioned, I went to the free clinic about a week after I found out—so that would've been around 9 weeks, I guess? I wasn't sure where else to go, honestly. I don't have insurance, and I knew the free clinic wouldn't turn me away.

*shifts uncomfortably*

The experience was... okay, I mean. The staff was nice enough, not judgmental or anything. They did a pregnancy test to confirm, took some basic information, asked about my medical history. They gave me some pamphlets about prenatal care and nutrition, stuff like that. 

*fidgets with hands*

But here's the thing—it felt kind of rushed, you know? I was only there for maybe 20 minutes total. They didn't really go into a lot of detail about what to expect or answer a lot of my questions. I had questions, but I felt like I was holding up the line or something. And they mentioned I should be taking prenatal vitamins, but they didn't really explain *why* or help me figure out how to get them affordably.

*looks up*

Since then, I haven't been back. I know I probably should schedule another appointment, but... *trails off* I guess I'm not sure what to expect, and honestly, it's hard to get time off work. Plus, I'm still kind of uncertain about everything, so part of me is like, why go if I'm not even sure I'm keeping it?

*pauses, realizing what she said*

I mean... I don't know. I'm just confused right now.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs and leans back in chair*

So right now, it's just the free clinic. I don't have a specific OB or midwife or anything like that. It's whoever is available when I go in, which I know isn't ideal. The last time I was there, I saw a nurse practitioner, I think? Or maybe a physician's assistant—I'm honestly not totally sure. She was nice, but like I said, the visit was pretty quick.

*rubs face tiredly*

I don't really have a "relationship" with a healthcare provider, if I'm being honest. It's more like... I go in when I need something, they help me, and then I leave. There's no continuity or anything. I don't know if I'll see the same person next time I go back.

*looks down*

And that's part of why I haven't gone back yet, I think. If I had someone I could call with questions or someone who knew my situation and could help me figure things out, that might be different. But calling the free clinic just feels like... I don't know, like I'm taking up resources that someone else might need more?

*pauses*

My mom keeps telling me I should try to find an OB or at least get set up with someone regular, but I don't know how to do that without insurance. And honestly, I'm worried about the cost. Even if I could find someone, what if I can't afford it?

*looks up at interviewer*

Is that something you see a lot with people in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs a bit awkwardly*

Well, that's kind of the problem, isn't it? I've only had the one appointment so far. So I don't really have a "typical" visit to walk you through, because I haven't established any kind of regular schedule yet.

*fidgets with the hem of her shirt*

From what I understand, I'm supposed to be going in regularly—like, every month or something? And then more often as I get further along? But nobody really sat down and explained that to me clearly. The nurse practitioner or whoever it was just kind of said, "Make an appointment for next month," but she didn't give me a specific date or anything. It was all pretty vague.

*looks frustrated*

And honestly, I've been putting it off. Work has been crazy, and I'm still just... I'm still wrapping my head around all of this. Plus, I don't know if I'm supposed to call and schedule or just show up, or what the process even is.

*pauses, then continues*

From what little I remember from that first visit, they took my blood pressure, asked me a bunch of questions about my health history, did the pregnancy test. They talked about symptoms and stuff. But like I said, it was quick. No ultrasound or anything like that, which I was kind of hoping for, honestly. I wanted to see the baby.

*looks at interviewer earnestly*

Should I be going more often? What should I be expecting at these appointments?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and thinks for a moment*

Um, well... I mean, nothing serious that I know of. I've had the usual pregnancy stuff, I guess? Like, I'm tired all the time—like, exhausted. And my boobs are still tender. I've had some nausea, especially in the mornings, though it's gotten a bit better in the last week or so.

*shifts in seat*

I've also noticed I'm getting headaches more often than I used to, and my sinuses have been acting up. Actually, I had viral sinusitis a few months ago—before I was pregnant—and it kind of comes and goes. I'm not sure if that's related to the pregnancy or if it's just something separate.

*rubs her gums absently*

And my gums have been bleeding when I brush my teeth. I know I have gingivitis—I've had that for a while—so that's probably just getting worse or something.

*looks uncertain*

But I don't know if any of this is... like, normal pregnancy stuff or if it's something I should be worried about. Nobody really explained that to me. I've been trying to Google things, but then I just end up scaring myself with all the worst-case scenarios, you know?

*pauses*

Oh, and I guess I should mention—I'm still smoking sometimes. Not a lot, but like, when I'm stressed or at work, I'll have a cigarette. I know that's probably not good, especially now, but I haven't really quit or anything.

*looks at interviewer with some concern*

Is any of this stuff something I should be worried about?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and looks a bit sheepish*

Honestly? Nothing right now. I'm not taking any prenatal vitamins or anything like that. Like I mentioned earlier, they told me I should be at that first clinic visit, but I haven't actually gotten any or started taking them.

*rubs the back of her neck*

I don't have any chronic conditions or anything, so I'm not on any regular medications. I mean, sometimes I'll take over-the-counter stuff if I have a headache or something—like ibuprofen or acetaminophen—but nothing regularly.

*thinks for a moment*

Oh, and I guess I should mention—when I had that viral sinusitis a few months ago, they gave me something for that, but I finished it and never refilled it. And my gingivitis... I haven't really done anything about that either. I just brush my teeth and try to floss, but it's not getting better.

*looks down*

I know I should probably be taking prenatal vitamins, especially since I'm already 16 weeks along. But like, I haven't really prioritized it. I don't know where to get them or how much they cost, and honestly, part of me is still in that weird headspace where I'm not fully accepting everything yet.

*looks up at interviewer*

Is it too late to start taking them now? And what exactly should I be taking? I feel like there's so much I don't know, and I don't even know where to start asking questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs a bit self-consciously*

Oh man, um... okay, so my diet is probably not great, if I'm being honest.

*shifts uncomfortably*

I work retail, so my schedule is kind of all over the place. Some days I'm opening the store at 6 AM, other days I'm closing at 9 PM. So a lot of the time, I'm grabbing whatever is convenient—fast food, stuff from the break room at work, you know? Like, I'll hit up the drive-thru on my way to work or grab a sandwich from the deli counter.

*rubs face tiredly*

I don't really cook much at home. My fiancé and I are both pretty busy, and honestly, I'm exhausted most of the time anyway. So we end up ordering takeout or getting frozen dinners a lot. I know that's not ideal, especially now that I'm pregnant, but...

*trails off*

I do try to eat some fruits and vegetables sometimes. I'll grab an apple or some carrots if they're available. And I drink a lot of soda—like, probably too much soda. I know I should probably switch to water or something, but the caffeine helps when I'm tired.

*looks down at hands*

I'm already overweight, and I know I should probably be more careful about what I'm eating, but I'm not really sure what I'm supposed to be doing differently. Like, how much weight am I supposed to gain? What should I actually be eating? Nobody really went over that with me.

*pauses*

I guess I'm just kind of eating like I normally do, which probably isn't the best thing for the baby, right?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a shaky breath and looks away for a moment*

Oh man... that's... that's a lot, honestly.

*fidgets with hands*

I mean, I'm scared. Like, really scared. I wasn't planning this, and even though my fiancé is supportive, I'm terrified about what this means for my life, you know? I'm only 24. I feel like I'm supposed to have more time before all this happens. And I'm not sure I'm ready to be a mom.

*voice gets quieter*

There's also this guilt thing happening. Like, I feel guilty that I'm not more excited or happy about it. I see pregnant women on social media who are just glowing and thrilled, and I'm over here still smoking and eating fast food and not taking vitamins. What kind of mother does that make me?

*looks up with watery eyes*

And then there's the uncertainty about whether I even want to go through with it. I know that sounds terrible, but... I don't know if I'm ready for this. My fiancé wants to keep it, I think, but we haven't really had a deep conversation about it. My mom is excited, which makes me feel even more guilty for not being excited.

*rubs face*

I'm also stressed about money, about work, about healthcare... it's just a lot. Some days I feel okay, and other days I just feel overwhelmed and anxious. I've been kind of isolating myself because I don't want to tell people yet, and that's making me feel lonely.

*pauses*

I don't know if I'm depressed or if this is just normal pregnancy stuff. But I'm definitely not in a good headspace right now.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a moment to collect thoughts*

Um, well... my fiancé is definitely my main support, I guess. He's been really understanding about everything, even though we didn't plan this. He comes to work with me sometimes just to check in, and he listens when I'm freaking out. He wants to keep the baby, which is... it's good that he's on board, but it also puts pressure on me, you know?

*counts on fingers*

My mom is supportive too. She's excited about being a grandmother, which is sweet, but like I said, it also makes me feel guilty for not matching her enthusiasm. She keeps sending me articles about pregnancy and baby stuff, and she's offered to help with things, but... I don't know, I'm not ready to fully accept it all yet, so her excitement sometimes feels overwhelming.

*looks down*

Other than that, honestly? My support network is pretty small. I have a couple of friends from work, but I haven't told them I'm pregnant yet. I'm not close with my extended family—my dad and I don't really talk much. And my fiancé's family... we're okay, but we're not super close either.

*pauses, looking uncertain*

I think part of the problem is that I'm keeping this to myself so much. I'm not really talking to anyone about how scared I am or how uncertain I feel. My fiancé knows some of it, but I don't want to burden him too much, you know? And my mom would just try to fix everything or tell me I'm being silly for worrying.

*looks at interviewer*

Do you think I should be talking to someone about all this? Like, a counselor or something?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs nervously and shakes head*

Birth plan? Um... honestly, I haven't really thought that far ahead. I mean, I know intellectually that I'm going to have to give birth at some point, but it still feels so far away, you know? I'm only 16 weeks. That's like... five more months?

*shifts uncomfortably in seat*

I guess I haven't really let myself think about it because that would mean fully accepting that this is actually happening. And like I said, I'm still kind of in denial about the whole thing.

*pauses, looking uncertain*

But I mean... if I'm being honest, I don't know anything about birth plans or what my options even are. Do I have options? I just kind of assumed you go to a hospital and they... do what they do, I guess? I've heard people talk about natural birth versus C-sections or epidurals or whatever, but I don't really understand the differences or what I would prefer.

*rubs arms*

I'm also terrified, to be completely honest. Like, I know birth is painful and there are risks and complications that can happen. I've heard horror stories from people. So I don't even know if I have preferences or if I'm just going to do whatever the doctors tell me to do.

*looks at interviewer earnestly*

Is this something I should be thinking about now? Should I have a birth plan already? I feel like I'm so far behind on everything...

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs and tucks hair behind ear*

Honestly? Mostly Google and like, random stuff on social media. Which I know is probably not the best source, but...

*shifts in seat*

When I first found out I was pregnant, I started Googling everything—like, what to expect, what symptoms are normal, all that stuff. But then I'd read something scary and spiral into panic mode, so I kind of stopped doing that as much. It's more stressful than helpful, you know?

*pulls out phone*

I'm on Instagram and TikTok, and sometimes I'll see pregnancy content pop up on my feed. Some of it's helpful—like, videos about what to eat or exercises you can do—but a lot of it is just... I don't know, people showing off their cute maternity photos or talking about how magical pregnancy is. Which is great for them, I guess, but it doesn't really help me figure out what I'm supposed to be doing.

*puts phone away*

My mom has sent me some articles and links to websites, but I haven't really read through them all. They're sitting in my email somewhere. And I got those pamphlets from the clinic, but like... I haven't really gone through them in detail.

*looks down*

I think the problem is that I don't have a trusted source, you know? Like, someone who can actually explain things to me in a way that makes sense and answers my specific questions. The internet is overwhelming, and I don't know what's accurate and what's not.

*pauses*

Have you heard of any good resources or websites I should be looking at?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*lets out a long, stressed sigh*

Oh man, um... honestly? I'm not really managing it. That's probably a big part of why I'm avoiding thinking about all of this.

*fidgets with hands nervously*

Like, I don't have health insurance, so I'm relying on the free clinic right now. But I know that's not going to cover everything—especially when it comes time to actually give birth. I've heard that hospital bills can be thousands of dollars, and I just... I don't have that kind of money.

*voice gets quieter*

My fiancé has some insurance through his job, but it's not great coverage, and I don't think I'm on his plan yet. We haven't really figured out if I can be added or what that would even look like. That's something we probably should have dealt with already, but we just... haven't.

*rubs face tiredly*

As for preparing for a baby—like, buying stuff—I haven't really done anything. I don't have a crib, or clothes, or diapers, or any of that. I know babies are expensive, and honestly, the thought of trying to afford all that stuff on top of everything else just makes me feel even more overwhelmed and panicked.

*looks down*

My mom has offered to help buy some things, and I think my fiancé's family might chip in too, but I don't want to ask for help. It feels like admitting that I can't handle this on my own, you know?

*pauses, looking genuinely worried*

I don't even know where to start with the financial stuff. Should I be looking into assistance programs or something? Is there help available for people in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*shifts uncomfortably in seat*

Well, so far I haven't told my manager or anyone at work that I'm pregnant, so it hasn't officially affected anything yet. But honestly? I'm already worried about what's going to happen when I do tell them.

*rubs arms nervously*

I work retail management, which means I'm on my feet a lot, dealing with customers, doing inventory, opening and closing the store. It's physically demanding, and with how exhausted I am all the time, it's getting harder. Like, by the end of my shift, my feet are killing me and I'm just completely drained.

*pauses*

I haven't taken any time off for appointments yet because I've only had the one clinic visit, and I didn't want to draw attention to anything. But I know I'm going to need to start scheduling regular prenatal appointments, and that means I'm going to have to either ask for time off or figure out how to work around it. And I'm worried about how my manager is going to react.

*looks uncertain*

I don't know what my rights are as a pregnant employee, honestly. Like, can they fire me for being pregnant? Can they cut my hours? I've heard stories about people losing their jobs after getting pregnant, and that terrifies me because I need this job. I need the income.

*voice gets quieter*

And then there's the whole maternity leave thing. I don't know if I get any, or if it's paid, or how long I can take off. I haven't even looked into it because that would mean admitting this is really happening and I'm going to have to deal with all these logistics.

*looks at interviewer*

I'm basically just trying to keep my head down and not think about it until I absolutely have to.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*looks startled by the question and laughs nervously*

The postpartum period? Um... no, honestly, I haven't really thought about that at all. That feels even further away than the birth itself, you know?

*shifts uncomfortably*

I mean, intellectually, I know that after I give birth, there's going to be a baby that I have to take care of. Like, I know babies need to eat and sleep and have their diapers changed and all that. But I haven't really... I don't know, made any actual plans or thought through what that's going to look like for me.

*rubs face tiredly*

I guess I haven't thought about things like... how long I can take off work, what childcare is going to look like, how I'm going to afford daycare if I go back to work. My fiancé and I haven't really talked about whether one of us would stay home or if we'd both be working. We haven't talked about any of it, really.

*voice gets quieter*

And honestly? I'm terrified about the actual recovery part too. I've heard that postpartum recovery is rough—like, painful and exhausting and emotional. And I'm already not in a great headspace mentally. I'm worried about postpartum depression or just... not being able to handle it all.

*looks down at hands*

My mom has mentioned that she could help out, maybe come stay with us for a bit after the baby is born, but I haven't asked her to or made any concrete plans. It's all just kind of... floating out there in the distance, and I'm not ready to think about it yet.

*pauses, looking vulnerable*

I feel like I'm supposed to have all this figured out by now, but I don't have any of it figured out. Does that make sense?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods slowly, looking both relieved and somewhat emotional*

Yeah, um... thank you for listening, I guess. It was actually kind of nice to just talk about all of this out loud, you know? I don't really get to do that very often.

*stands up and gathers belongings*

I appreciate that you didn't judge me or make me feel worse about everything. I already feel pretty guilty about a lot of this stuff, so... yeah.

*pauses at the door, looking back*

I hope this information is helpful for whatever research you're doing. And I guess... I don't know, maybe talking about it like this will help me actually start dealing with things instead of just avoiding them all the time.

*manages a small smile*

My mom's always saying I need to be more proactive about my health and my future, and I guess she's right. I just... I need to figure out how to get past this denial thing, you know?

*extends hand for a handshake*

Thanks again. And if you have any of those resources or information about assistance programs or anything like that, I'd actually appreciate it. Maybe it's time I started getting my act together.

---

**END OF INTERVIEW**

*Interview conducted: [Date]*
*Persona: Samantha, 24-year-old, G1P0, 16 weeks gestation*
*Key findings: Limited prenatal care access, financial barriers, emotional uncertainty, inadequate health literacy, minimal social support structure, delayed prenatal interventions*

persona_traceability.description: Samantha is a 24-year-old retail manager living in suburban Atlanta with a high school diploma and a lower-middle income. She is engaged and has limited access to healthcare, relying on occasional visits to a free clinic. Samantha is overweight, sedentary, and smokes occasionally, but has no chronic conditions. This is her first pregnancy (G1P0), and she is uncertain about her pregnancy plans, not currently taking prenatal vitamins.
